12:45.race_name: "Get Your Ladbrokes Free Kempton Bet" Novices' Limited Handicap Chase (GBB Race)

runners.comment: Two game wins at Exeter since switched to fences; another gritty display is on the cards
runners.name: U Cant Be Serious

quotes.race: Stables Business Park Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: U Can't Be Serious had some cracking bumper form last season and he was always going to need the run at Exeter to bring him on. We haven't got any plans but he looks a nice sort and we'll probably go somewhere under a penalty next. Joe Tizzard, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Record of 3-3 over 2m3f includes two game wins at Exeter (good to soft) since switched to fences; open to further improvement at this sort of distance and should make a tenacious bid to defy top weight.

stable_tour.quote: He looks a nice novice chaser. He's entered at Exeter on Monday in a couple of races. He's a big, strong chap who is more than capable of winning a few races off his mark. 12-11-25

runners.comment: He was in the process of showing promise when badly hampered on chase/stable debut
runners.name: Queensbury Boy

quotes.race: Watch Weekend Winners Powered By BetVictor Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The only horse that's beaten him is Wingmen, who has placed in a couple of Grade 1s and is rated 139. We're very lucky to have him. Queensbury Boy ran very well at Punchestown last year and while it's a big step up in grade, he has class and he's also fresh,. A lot of these talented horses have had tough winters, whereas Queensbury Boy hasn't. He's a novice until the autumn, so the Persian War will definitely be in our mind. I know one of Davids [Maxwell, owner-jockey] dreams is to win the Cheltenham hunter chase. It's a long time off, obviously, but hopefully he'll be that standard one day - Harry Derham, jockey, speaking to Sky Sports Racing.

quotes.race: Livescore Bet Best Odds Daily Maiden Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Queensbury Boy is a very nice horse. He's very straightforward and I think we'll run him in a nice novice hurdle somewhere. He's a chaser for next year and I'm really looking forward to that - David Maxwell, owner/rider.

runners.spotlight: Point/bumper/hurdles winner; in the process of showing promise when badly hampered by final-fence faller at Cheltenham (2m4f) last time on chase/stable debut; could go well, provided he gets better luck.

stable_tour.quote: After winning his point-to-point, he ran in two bumpers last season, winning at Chepstow before finishing a good second at Punchestown. He'll probably start at the Hennessy meeting and is a well-above-average novice hurdler. 01-11-24

runners.comment: Ex-Irish; something to find on his two efforts for new yard, latest switched to fences
runners.name: Krak

quotes.race: Bar One Racing Easter Handicap Hurdle
quotes.quote: Krak had three nice runs in maidens. It was a good performance because it is not easy first time in a handicap, you need to be streetwise but he did it well. He has been a bit babyish on his previous runs and a bit immature but he had no choice there today, my hand was forced to sit where I was, I couldn't be any closer. I think there's improvement to come from him and who knows where he'll end up. Hopefully he'll keep climbing the ranks. He's going to be penalised now for this so we'll see what happens after that. He warmed into it well and he came home well - J J Slevin, jockey.

runners.spotlight: Off the mark in 2m3f handicap hurdle on final Irish start; has something to find on his two efforts for new yard, latest at Sandown (1m7f) switched to fences; however, has low mileage and may do better still.

runners.comment: Two from two since switched to chasing; form of easy success last time has been franked
runners.name: Noble Park

quotes.race: Get The Inside Track With raceday-ready.com Novices' Limited Handicap Chase (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The handicapper probably isn't going to be very nice to Noble Park for that, but I was very happy with him and he jumped well. He's obviously improved for fences and is going the right way - James Bowen, jockey.

runners.spotlight: Maiden prior to winning twice since switched to chasing, last time in easy fashion at Lingfield (2m4f, good; runner-up has franked the form since); may well improve further and cope with 11lb rise; respected.

stable_tour.quote: We're getting there with him. He's run some very respectable races but we tried to keep him for the £100,000 race at Punchestown and it wasn't far enough for him. He jumps fences really well so we'll go novice chasing and he'll go up in trip. 21-10-25

runners.comment: Generally progressive mare who is a point/bumper/hurdles winner; one to consider
runners.name: Jasmine Bliss
runners.owner: Noel Fehily Racing Syndicate - Jasmine B

quotes.race: Stewart Wright Memorial Mares' Open National Hunt Flat Race (Category 1 Elimination) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Jasmine Bliss is very good and it's difficult to do that with a penalty. She's really exciting for novice hurdling next season and that's when you'll see her next - she's finished for this term as she's run three times already. She's a fantastic jumper and will start over two miles over hurdles, but she'll soon want two and a half as you saw the way she galloped there - Harry Derham, trainer.

quotes.race: Racing TV On Sky 426 Mares' Open Maiden National Hunt Flat Race (Category 3 Elimination) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Jasmine Bliss is a very nice mare. She was a bit too fresh first time out but she was much better today and she'll go to Sandown for the Listed mares' bumper in the spring - Harry Derham, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Generally progressive mare who is a point and dual bumper/hurdles winner; bit disappointing in a notable handicap when last seen but may still have more to offer; should take well to chasing; one to consider.

stable_tour.quote: She's a four-time winner for me who'll now go chasing, although she won't be ready until Christmas or after. She had a breathing operation with Noel Fehily through the summer so she's back late to me. She found her level over hurdles. She's tough and a particularly good jumper. 19-11-25

She'll go chasing and has been crying out for fences. She had a good season over hurdles and the ground was probably a bit quick for her in the EBF Mares' Final at Newbury on her final start. 22-10-25

runners.comment: In good form over 2m since switched to fences and should be as effective back up in trip
runners.name: Secret Des Dieux
runners.spotlight: Fairly useful form over 2m since switched to fences, winning comfortably at Fakenham then third at Newbury, both on good to soft; shaped last time as if this step back up in trip will suit; not ruled out.

stable_tour.quote: He's done well over hurdles but he's schooled fantastic over fences and I think he's an out-and-out two-mile chaser. He's almost ready to go and should give us some fun over fences. 24-10-25
He has won his last two starts over hurdles at Fakenham and Hereford. He's owned by a loyal supporter of mine, Mr Betts, and he returns to Fakenham on New Year's Day for a handicap hurdle. 01-01-25

runners.comment: Lightly raced; weighted to reverse Exeter reappearance placings with U Cant Be Serious
runners.name: Barlovento

quotes.race: Get The Inside Track With raceday-ready.com Open Maiden National Hunt Flat Race (Cat 3 Elim') (GBB)
quotes.quote: Barlovento was in front for a long time and got lonely but we've always liked him and he's got a bright future. He's for sale and will hopefully be in different colours next time he's on a racecourse - Olly Murphy, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Lightly raced bumper/hurdle winner; had wind surgery prior to half-length second behind U Cant Be Serious at Exeter (2m3f, good to soft) on chase/seasonal debut; gets a 7lb pull with that rival; possibilities.

runners.comment: Should make a chaser and he's bred to take well to this scenario; interesting contender
runners.name: Epic West

quotes.race: Winners Choose My Pension Expert Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Epic West was fairly green and was pricking his ears, so I think it was a pretty good performance. He had a couple of runs in point-to-points in Ireland but that was his first start under rules. He's got the pedigree to be a proper three-mile chaser in time and the physique for that, but to show enough speed to win over two miles was quite nice and hopefully he's got a nice future. I would have thought we'll be looking towards something like the EBF Final as Complete Unknown, his half-brother, won it a couple of years ago. It would look ideal - Jamie Snowden, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Solid record in points and novice hurdles, producing form figures of 21112; should make a chaser and he's bred to take well to this scenario (best sibling won a useful handicap in sole C&D attempt); interesting.

stable_tour.quote: won his point-to-point at Belclare. He'll also go novice hurdling this winter but looks made for a fence. 06-11-24
He won two of his three novice hurdle starts last season, which was great. He jumps fences really well and he'll go novice handicap chasing. He's a nice horse. 05-11-25

runners.breeder: Stephen Kemble Bloodstock Ltd & G Peck
runners.comment: Recent form includes a Wincanton win but he's a lot more exposed than today's rivals
runners.name: Tapley
runners.spotlight: Recent form includes a Wincanton success (2m4f) but his record of 1-6 over fences, combined with high overall mileage, reflects that he's a lot more exposed than today's opponents; opposed.

runners.comment: Largely consistent over hurdles but his form dipped sharply on chase/seasonal debut
runners.name: Lumi Plugin
runners.owner: J Hinds, A Head & G L Moore
runners.spotlight: Largely consistent over hurdles but his form dipped sharply at Chepstow (2m3f) on chase/seasonal debut; while a rebound is possible, others have stronger claims as things stand.

stable_tour.quote: He's honest and could end up running in three-mile chases this season. He's been mainly running over shorter, but he looks like a staying chaser and that's the way he's heading. 28-10-25

13:20.race_name: Ladbrokes Kauto Star Novices' Chase (In Memory Of Nigel Clark) (Grade 1) (GBB Race)

runners.comment: Entitled to win a Grade 2 at Wincanton (2m4f, good) a lot more easily than he did
runners.name: Blueking Doroux

prev_owners.owner: Patrice Puyravaud, Arnaud Chaille-Chaille Et Al

quotes.race: Boodles Rising Stars Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Blueking D'Oroux obviously stays well, but we always thought he perhaps didn't want three miles, but I think three miles might just help his jumping a little bit in time. It was a good effort today and he got there when he needed to. He is just a bit careful. He is not like a big, bold, scopey horse that takes them on. He is always backing off a bit which makes it hard work for you, but he has stuck his head down and galloped all the way to the line. He was brilliant at the last, but he needed that. The second horse is no mug as we have been up against him this summer with Centara. His jumping just cost him at Newton Abbot a little bit. It is all experience, and this is what novice chases are about getting experience for the future. I'm delighted with him. Windsor might be a bit tight for him, and he doesn't want it too soft as he went there last year and hated it. He can't be silly handicapped over fences if you take his two runs over fences. Handicapping on his chase form will be less than his hurdles form so you never know that could be an option. If he hadn't done that today he would have probably gone back over hurdles. I've got no set plan at the moment - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: bet365 Select Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Blueking D'Oroux loves good ground and I thought he'd go well today. This was the perfect race before he goes chasing. He'll be a better chaser than he was a hurdler. He jumps well and stays nicely, so he'll be a fun horse. He's the mirror of Pic D'Orhy and you'd be happy if he turns out like him - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Coral Hurdle (Grade 2) (Registered As The Ascot Hurdle) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We were hopeful of \Blueking D'Oroux today but we didn't know what he would do, so we haven't made any big plans. I think he has a bit of class, I really do. We were pretty disappointed with the first two runs and we couldn't think of anything else to do but give him a breathing op and it's transformed him. Everything he's done at home has just got better and better - he was hard to train last year but isn't anymore. It's hard to say because I was cheering so much, but it looked like he was just staying and staying, so whether we end up going three miles with him, we'll see. Typically it's a weaker division, so it might make sense. That's a pretty strong performance I'd say - Johnny de la Hey, owner.

quotes.race: Masterson Holdings Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Blueking D'Oroux is a nice horse. On ratings he was entitled to win and we had him ready for today. He has improved so much for last season's wind operation, as he was a disaster at the start of last season. The Greatwood Hurdle would have to be under serious consideration now. If not Johnny (de la Hey) likes having runners at Ascot so we could wait and take him there - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Royal Ascot Racing Club Juvenile Handicap Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We were confident earlier in the season at Cheltenham in a Grade 2. Blueking D'Oroux did some great work before that but ran a stinker. He ran poorly after that as well. We gambled on a wind operation. It wasn't obvious that was the problem. I just think he's grown up a bit. To be honest, we thought he was badly handicapped off 127 but I didn't think he was a 50-1 shot. That was quite crazy. When you turn in like that, you're there to be picked off but he kept galloping, which was encouraging. I actually think he probably needs further. He's not Cyrname but that was decent enough - Johnny de la Hey, owner.

runners.spotlight: The winner of two Grade 2s (2m3f/2m5f; good ground) over hurdles; still early days but he hasn't looked a natural chaser and was entitled to win a Grade 2 at Wincanton (2m4f, good) a lot more easily than he did, the form of which has taken some knocks; however, his hurdling ability is respected and it could be that he now needs 3m.

stable_tour.quote: Given his smart hurdles form, I have always entertained hopes he'll turn out to be one of our leading novice chasers this season, and the plan was always to give him one run over fences and then go for the Grade 2 Rising Stars Novices' Chase. Even though he got beaten first time up last month, we're still going to stick to the plan and go for the Wincanton race. It's worth noting both Silviniaco Conti and Knappers Hill got beaten on their chasing debuts before winning the Rising Stars on their second run. Of course I would have preferred it if he'd won at Newton Abbot, but he was clearly a bit rusty and didn't jump as fluently as the winner, who is an experienced handicapper and the winner of a Grade 2. He'll come on a ton and be a lot sharper for the experience when he reappears at Wincanton on Saturday and I still have high hopes for him - this weekend and for the whole season. He's not over-big for chasing but that won't hinder him. 04-11-25

runners.breeder: R D & Mrs J S Chugg
runners.comment: Already looks a promising chaser but he's held by Wendigo on their Newbury clash
runners.name: Crest Of Fortune

quotes.race: Oddschecker Sefton Novices' Hurdle (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We thought with this type of race it would suit Crest Of Fortune rather than run in a handicap. His hurdling wasn't really good enough as it proved today. He wouldn't have gotten in any of the handicaps and we just thought today he could sit mid pack and his pedigree suggested going up to three miles. We didn't want to go three miles all season. He might well be going chasing next season but we will see. He is a big baby still - Anthony Honeyball, trainer.

quotes.race: JPR Phoenix Maiden Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We're hoping Crest Of Fortune will make into a Graded novice horse. He's gone and done it straight away, so we'll try and look after him now and see what the best sort of programme is for him. He's only four, so we don't want to over-face him, but he's a nice horse and his jumping was good enough for us to run him in a nice novice now. He was quite fresh, but he's straightforward at home and is very relaxed in his work. He'll have learned plenty about being in a bigger field and he's a gorgeous looking horse. Although he did a bit wrong in terms of how keen he was, he came through it like a nice horse and put the race to bed quite soon - Anthony Honeyball, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Won a maiden and a novice over hurdles and later third in a Grade 1 at Aintree (3m, good; his only run in today's reapplied tongue-tie); he's already looking every bit as good over fences despite two defeats, but he has near enough 10l to find with Wendigo on their clash in a 2m4f Grade 2 at Newbury four weeks ago; this longer trip could trigger improvement, but the same can be said for the winner.

stable_tour.quote: He really took the eye at Ffos Las on Sunday. He was fresh and keen and didn't really help himself, which he isn't normally like at home, but he jumped fluently and put in a really strong performance. He looks a smart horse and we're hoping he'll be a Graded novice hurdler. I'd like to think he'll end up in the top races - he's got a good pedigree and he's spot on in every way at home. We'll try and make the most of this season and something like an introductory hurdle would be ideal next. 14-11-24

He's unraced but has a smart pedigree - the dam got black type and bred a nice horse with Gordon Elliott, Pour Les Filles, who was fifth in the Aintree bumper in April. We'll train him for the sales bumper at Newbury in March, which we won for the same owners last season. It might be handy to get a run into him before that, purely from a ballot perspective, but he's a nice youngster. 12-10-23

runners.comment: Smart hurdler who looked good on his chase debut; worth another crack at 3m
runners.name: Kitzbuhel

prev_owners.owner: Mme M Juhen-Cypres, D S De Beauregard & Mme T De Beauregard

quotes.race: Conway Piling Beginners Chase
quotes.quote: Kitzbuhel needed that. It was a nice performance, he jumped economically and Paul [Townend] was happy that he'd improve from that. We'll look for a race after Christmas, maybe the one at Limerick - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Red Mills Trial Hurdle (Grade 3)
quotes.quote: I love the way Kitzbuhel jumped, he'd have no trouble going over fences. I loved the way he stayed on when it looked like the race was over when he was taken on by Sir Gerhard and he had to find again to take on the challenge of Break My Soul. It's the sign of a real good horse that he was able to pick up a second time. I'm probably looking at Liverpool more so than Cheltenham. With the timing of the race and the two and a half miles for the Liverpool Hurdle, Aintree would be a big possibility. I think he'd love to step up in trip and I'd have no problem going three miles - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Members Club 2025 Hurdle
quotes.quote: He was very professional. I think Kitzbuhel will stay further, he surprised me the way he quickened into the straight - Paul Townend, jockey, speaking to Racing TV.

runners.spotlight: Grade-3 winning hurdler who signed off last season with a close third (staying on) behind Blueking d'Oroux and Salver in a 2m5f Grade 2 at Sandown (good); did everything right in justifying odds-on favouritism on chase debut in a good race at Punchestown (2m3f; soft to heavy) and this longer trip is worth exploring again, for all that he faded in a 3m Grade 1 hurdle at Aintree last season.

stable_tour.quote: He did well over hurdles last season, but I'd like to think there's more to come from him over fences. He's a fine stamp of a horse who should really take to chasing. He wants a trip. 17-11-25

runners.comment: Good hurdler and the 12l winner of a 3m Grade 2 on second chase start; up to this level
runners.name: Salver

quotes.race: Betfair Esher Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We expected Doyen Quest would go out ahead, and when that happened it made Salver jump better. It brought the best out of him. Ideally he needs soft but I had a walk of the track earlier and down the back it's good, good to soft ground. He excelled when he got on to the soft part of the track. The big obvious target would be Boxing day at Kempton. If there's slow-enough ground you'd think to go there, but maybe over this trip the ground doesn't come into it as much. Caoilin [Quinn] said he was better the more pressure he put on, so he's a lovely horse to have in the yard - Josh Moore, joint-trainer.

quotes.race: Virgin Bet Victor Ludorum Juvenile Hurdle (Go North Grey Bomber Series Qualifier) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Salver has done it nicely, it was a case of he's done what he had to do. It's proper heavy ground out there and he goes on it and copes with the conditions. Cheltenham will be ground dependent - I think he'll only be going there if it's soft or worse than soft. If it's a good ground Triumph, I can't see him running there. He's a nice horse - Josh Moore, assistant trainer.

quotes.race: Coral Finale Juvenile Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Salver loves soft ground and enjoyed the conditions, whereas the rest probably didn't. He has already done more than I expected and he isn't just going to be a juvenile, either, because he is a big horse and can only improve. His jumping today was unbelievable as well. He was gaining lengths at every hurdle. I'll have to think about a better race now and we might have to look at the Triumph Hurdle, but if it came up quick at Cheltenham we wouldn't have to run him. We could wait for Aintree or just put him away - Gary Moore, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Smart hurdler, although he received 3lb from Blueking d'Oroux when narrowly held by the latter in a 2m5f Grade 2 at Sandown last April (good; prefers softer); third in his first chase to the exciting Lulamba but that was over 2m1f and he easily saw off his three rivals when upped to 3m at Sandown (Grade 2; good to soft); his jumping there was a bit sketchy early doors but improved as the race progressed; ability and potential are much respected.

stable_tour.quote: Depending on there being some rain, he'll hopefully start off over fences at either Sandown or Ascot next month. He'll step up in trip as the season goes on but he's not a slow horse, so there's no rush, and he's schooled very well. He's been highly tried over hurdles but I think he'll improve for going over a fence. 28-10-25

runners.comment: Beat two notable rivals at Ascot when back chasing and he shouldn't be passed over lightly
runners.name: Thomas Mor

quotes.race: Get Your Ladbrokes Free Ascot Bet 'Chasing Excellence' Beginners' Chase (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Ben [Jones, jockey] said Thomas Mor was a little outpaced in the middle, so he had to sit and suffer, but he came there in the end and he was given a good ride - Johnson White, joint-trainer.

quotes.race: Pertemps Network Handicap Hurdle (Pertemps Hurdle Series Qualifier) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It was great Thomas Mor could do it after such a long layoff. I've had him around three months and I was delighted with him. He's obviously a thorough stayer and he's a big horse too, so he's taken a fair bit of time to get ready - but he's ready now. He's lovely but he's also quite good. I've no idea what we'll do now as we were going novice chasing. His form from before is good, he obviously retains his ability and although he's eight, hopefully there will be room for improvement because he hasn't run that much - Philip Hobbs, joint-trainer.

quotes.race: Lenny Roberts Memorial Trophy Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I think that race might have fallen apart and when we took the favourite on, that played to our advantage. I don't think Thomas Mor will want it winter soft, but we'll see. He's a lovely type and will be chasing down the line - David Pipe, trainer

runners.spotlight: Lightly raced for an 8yo; by no means the best of these over hurdles (albeit useful) but he's now 4-4 on right-handed tracks after beating two notable rivals on his return to fences at Ascot one month ago (2m5f, good; stays 3m); that was workmanlike but he was well on top at the finish and shouldn't be passed over lightly.

stable_tour.quote: He's going chasing and we're starting off at Ascot on Friday. He won on his first start off a long break at Wincanton last season before going on to run well in the Pertemps. I'd like to think he can have a good season over fences. 20-11-25

He joined us after winning his point-to-point at Bartlemy last May and made an immediate impact, winning a maiden hurdle at Worcester. He then went to Wincanton where he was impressive. After that we upped him in class for the Challow Hurdle but it poured on the day and it was far too soft for him. He definitely prefers good ground and he bounced back to form at Ascot on Saturday, where he quickened up very well. He is in the Albert Bartlett at Cheltenham but we will wait and see what the handicapper does. Cheltenham is a big ask for a young horse and we will see what the owners want to do, but he is going make a cracking chaser. 22-02-23

runners.comment: This speed-orientated track might not play to his strengths but he'll be keeping on
runners.name: Wendigo

quotes.race: Coral John Francome Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Wendigo is a horse we've always loved. We couldn't wait to see him over a fence. We've been patient with him and that was a great performance. He's better on slightly softer and we know he stays further. Stamina probably won it and we'll be going up to three miles. He's a very classy individual and the future is bright. He was fifth in the Albert Bartlett and was a bit unlucky that day. The next race for him could be the Kauto Star over Christmas. I think he's marginally better left than right-handed but that's just a bit of a hunch - Jamie Snowden, trainer.

quotes.race: wetherbyracing.co.uk Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We were on a bit of a hiding to nothing at that kind of price in that sort of race, but it was nice to get a confidence-boosting run intoWendigo. He's going to improve by going up to three miles and hopefully we'll head to Cheltenham with half a chance - Jamie Snowden, trainer.

quotes.race: Coral Challow Novices' Hurdle (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We knew it'd take a career best from Wendigo to perform like that. He did that and he's a lovely horse going forward. We thought we'd dip our toe early to see where we are, but he'll be a lovely chaser next season - Jamie Snowden, trainer.

quotes.race: Pontesbury Tractors Case IH Red Power 'Introductory' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Wendigo is a stunning horse. He won two bumpers last year and improved from his hurdling debut. He looked great and it's a decent bit of prize-money the course have put on, so it looked a nice opportunity for him. He wants soft ground and stays well, so we expect him to make up into a staying chaser. We might have half a look at the Challow in December. He's smart - Jamie Snowden, trainer.

quotes.race: Langley Castle An Outstanding Small Hotel Open NH Flat Race (Go North Jodami Qual') (C1 Elim') (GBB)
quotes.quote: Wendigo is a nice horse, we like him a lot. It was a case of trying to win and get the job done and he's won well. That was fairly bad ground and he's only a four-year-old so we'll be patient with him, I'd have thought we could look at a better race now - Jamje Snowden, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Talented novice hurdler who finished runner-up to The New Lion in the Grade 1 Challow last Christmas (2m4f, good to soft) and ran well in the face of some adversity in the 3m Albert Bartlett; beaten by a subsequent Listed winner on chase debut but went one better in a Grade 2 at Newbury (again 2m4f) where never stronger than at the finish; this speed-orientated track might not play to his strengths but he'll be boxing on; respected.

stable_tour.quote: He was a lovely horse for us last season. He was second in the Challow and then finished fifth in the Albert Bartlett. He was lucky not to be pulled down at the second-last that day, but he stayed on well and would have finished third without that interference. He looked the class horse on his chase debut at Worcester last month when he was second. He travelled well and it takes nothing away from the calibre of horse we think he is. We'll probably go to the John Francome Novices' Chase at Newbury next, and he could be decent over fences this season. 05-11-25
He's lovely and ran in two point-to-points before winning one and he looks capable of adding to that in a bumper before we go novice hurdling. 28-09-23

runners.breeder: E A R L Haras Du Mondant Et Al
runners.comment: Chepstow win is strong handicap form; ran well in Ascot Grade 2 since; progressive
runners.name: Celtic Dino

quotes.race: Fitzdares Season Opener At Wincanton Maiden Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Celtic Dino got a bit hot before racing and has still got lots to learn, but it's nice to see them a bit green in the race as you know they're going to come on for it. Dylan [Johnston, jockey] was great and gave him a fantastic ride. The Betfair [Hurdle at Newbury in February] would be the obvious, and he'd need a run every month to qualify, but that would be the sort of thing we'd be looking at ideally. He's a top of the ground horse and pointed his toe, jumped great and I was pleased to see him just have a good look - Sam Thomas, trainer, talking to Racing TV.

runners.spotlight: Second-season hurdler whose reappearance win at Chepstow (2m, good; defied top weight) is very strong handicap form; ran well in Grade 2 event at Ascot (2m3f, good to soft) since, beating all bar talented mare Wodhooh; progressive contender who may well rate higher still and adds interest to this festive staple.

stable_tour.quote: The first main target this season was the Welsh Champion Hurdle and he won that well in a race that couldn't have worked out much better form-wise. We didn't want to go and run him on soft ground in the Greatwood Hurdle and I was over the moon with his second in the Ascot Hurdle. He was beaten by a classy mare and to give her 7lb and chase her home was a fine performance. I've not got a clue where we'll go next, but he's a Graded horse on top of the ground and a perfect one for the spring festivals. 23-11-25

He's a lovely horse but he's still quite raw and weak. We were pleased with the way he won on his debut in a bumper at Ascot and he ran well in a Listed contest last time. The time was very good and we lost nothing in defeat. He's a good mover with a brilliant pedigree so he's one to look forward to next season. I won't be rushing to run him over hurdles this campaign. 05-01-24

runners.comment: Came up short when bidding for six-timer (Flat/hurdles); this is a harder task
runners.name: Give It To Me Oj

quotes.race: Masterson Holdings Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It's a cliche but Give It To Me OJ could be anything - he honestly could be. His four-year-old season was always going to be harder but we could look at the Gerry Feilden Hurdle for him - Josh Moore, joint-trainer.

quotes.race: Geoff Lewis Apprentices' Derby Handicap (Supported By Betfred) (GBBPlus Race)
quotes.quote: Give It To Me Oj does everything so easily, he's a very talented horse. He's one to look out for this jumps season - Ashley Lewis, jockey.

quotes.race: Sash & Dash By Quickslide Jump Jockeys Derby Handicap (For Professional Jump Jockeys) (GBBPlus Race)
quotes.quote: We know Give It To Me Oj is very quick out of the stalls, so I just tried to dictate it from the front, and he's done it well. I got on well with him last season as a juvenile hurdler, but hopefully there are a few more Flat races he can win before he goes back hurdling. He's an exciting horse and we haven't seen the best of him yet - Caoilin Quinn, rider.

quotes.race: bet365 Novices' Championship Final Handicap Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Give It To Me Oj has always been a nice horse and has exceeded all our expectations today. For a four-year-old to carry 12 stone, is a very good performance. He will stick to hurdles next year. He will have a break now but he could also run on the Flat. He is still well handicapped on the Flat but we'll see how he comes out of this race. We will see what his handicap mark is, but he could start back in the Masterson Holdings Hurdle at Cheltenham or the Free Handicap Hurdle at Chepstow - Gary Moore, joint-trainer.

quotes.race: Get Best Odds Guaranteed At BetVictor Juvenile Hurdle (Novices' Championship Hurdle Qualifier) (GBB)
quotes.quote: Apart from the last, Give It To Me OJ jumped well. He was going a bit left-handed, but that might have been because the front horse was going left-handed. Through no fault of his own he's had a messed up season, but he needed that run the other day when he was second - Gary Moore, joint-trainer.

runners.spotlight: Completed a five-timer (Flat/hurdles) with his success in 4yo hurdle at Cheltenham (2m, good) in October; unable to sustain the sequence in notable handicap at Newbury since, coming up well short off a mark of 143; faces a harder assignment on these terms.

stable_tour.quote: He really got things together over hurdles last winter and finished the season well when winning under top weight at Sandown on finals day. As expected, he was well handicapped back on the Flat, winning twice at Epsom over the summer and he might yet go for the November Handicap. He's a big horse who was always going to do better with time, and his quality got him through when winning from the front at Cheltenham on Saturday. He'll be better than that over hurdles, and there's a Grade 3 for four-year-olds at Fairyhouse at the end of November to consider, although the Gerry Feilden at Newbury is more likely. Beyond that, what was the Betfair Hurdle in February is the sort of stiff test he wants and the County Hurdle might suit him at the end of the season. He's a proper horse to run over hurdles. 28-10-25

runners.breeder: B Decouz & S C E A Du Bas Bugey
runners.comment: Successful this autumn in races at Kempton and Wincanton that he's won twice previously
runners.name: Rubaud

prev_owners.owner: Sas Racing D & Olivier De Seyssel

quotes.race: BetMGM Elite Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Rubaud had a very hard race the other day at Kempton Park, and he knew he had a race the other day, and it took a while for him to get over it. I could tell in the paddock that he didn't look great in his coat, and he has been a bit flat this week. We have had to do the best we could to get him right. When we went to Kempton, he had a lot of hard work and he was ready for his life. This week we have had to do things a bit different to freshen him up. He is a good horse that is tough and keeps galloping. Testament to him as what a class horse he is that he can come back from a very hard race and win today. We know he is not going to win a Christmas Hurdle, so I don't want to waste a run. He has won two good races now and if he doesn't run until after Christmas I don't mind. He is the sort that could run well in the Silviniaco Conti Chase over two and a half miles as he won the Pendil there last season. There are no more Grade Two races like this until the Kingwell Hurdle back here or the International Hurdle at Cheltenham, but the ground is too soft for him there. The Kingwell will be a possibility - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Ladbrokes Pendil Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I am amazed Rubaud has won. I thought down the back he was in a bit of trouble. As Harry said, he hates ground that like. It's the first time he has won on soft ground and he's a much better horse on better ground. He had a hard enough race at Warwick the other day and two weeks is quick enough but he toughed it out and stayed on really strongly, which was a doubt over this trip. I'd say we'll freshen him up now and go to Aintree for the two and a half mile novices' chase (Manifesto Novices' Chase) - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: BetMGM Elite Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Rubaud is a fantastic horse and is improving. We'll go chasing now. He's a brilliant jumper, he's a big, scopey horse and that's his future now. We'll go to Kempton for the Wayward Lad but if we found a beginners chase we could look at that. I'd be happy to go straight to Kempton though.    He beat two good horses that are rated higher than him and giving them 6lb. He'll be brilliant when we go chasing - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: TrustATrader Approved And Reviewed Trades People Hurdle (Listed Race) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: That was awesome. Rubaud is going to be a chaser at some point, but I don't need to when there are good hurdle races and there are no novice chases at the moment. Wincanton is the obvious target, then go chasing after that - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: JenningsBet Elite Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The plan is to go to the Christmas Hurdle on Boxing Day then come back here for the Kingwell after Christmas. When these horses start improving you don't know where they'll end up and the Christmas Hurdle will give us a marker where we are. Someone has got to take Constitution Hill on. We'll go there and if we finished second we'll be delighted. Rubaud will be be a lovely two-mile chaser next season and we'll just pick our races with him this season - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Trustatrader Approved And Reviewed Trades People Hurdle (Listed Race) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I thought Rubaud looked big enough for his first run of the season, so he's going to improve and he'll go to Wincanton in three weeks for the Elite Hurdle. That was always the plan; here and Wincanton. He stays on strong and goes a good gallop, so I'm thrilled with him. It suits him going right-handed and we'll probably run him in the Christmas Hurdle as then as something has got to finish second to Constitution Hill. It's good prize-money so we'll go there and we'll stay hurdling this season and then go chasing next autumn as he's only five. We did think about fences, but I thought he'd improve hurdling and we just lacked a horse of what I'd call his calibre to do those Wincanton races, the Elite and Kingwell, which would suit him quite well. He doesn't want a bog, while he's not slow, but is a staying two-miler  - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Coral Scottish Champion Hurdle (A Limited Handicap) (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Rubaud had been a bit keen earlier in the season but we still thought we'd try to ride him positively. He's been improving all the time, it was the best thing I ever did not running him at Aintree last week on the soft ground. He'll be some two-mile chaser next season, I can't wait - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

quotes.race: Sky Bet Dovecote Novices' Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Rubaud won twice earlier in the season making all at Taunton. The ground was a bit soft here on Boxing Day, and the whole thing went wrong in the Betfair Hurdle as he got a bit lit up. Today was much better. He relaxed and jumped great and galloped on strong. He had a bit of form in France before he ran here last year but he made a bit of a noise and he bled that day, so he had his wind sorted out and we gave him some time. That was what he done earlier in the season at Taunton, he absolutely bolted in by going from the front. He is a good horse - he has just got to learn to relax a bit more. We won't go for the Supreme as we have Tahmuras for that and he is probably not ready for that. You are not going to dominate around there. Aintree is probably a bit easier for a front runner. I think a flat track suits him nicely and we will keep him nice and fresh, and though it is a big step up we will go for the Grade 1 over two miles at Aintree. The exciting thing is he will be a lovely two-mile chaser next season - Paul Nicholls, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Very useful front-runner who is 2-2 since returned to hurdles from fences, winning races at Kempton (Listed) and Wincanton (Elite Hurdle) that he also took in 2023 and 2024; however, no match for Constitution Hill in this contest two years ago and faces another Henderson star in this edition.

stable_tour.quote: What a wonderful horse! He began his season in the now usual manner, by winning the Listed hurdle at Kempton for the third year running. It was disappointing the feat merited little more than a passing mention in the press. We'll now seek to continue following a well-worn path and look at the Elite at Wincanton on Saturday, a race he has also won for the last two years. Alternatively, he could switch to the Haldon Gold Cup a day earlier if the ground at Exeter came up too fast for Kalif Du Berlais. His chasing career, which I'd long looked forward to, had been delayed last season because he was doing so well over hurdles, mopping up those Grade 2 prizes with regularity. He finally got to jump fences in public at Christmas when outclassed behind Sir Gino. We then lowered his sights and he gave L'Eau Du Sud a fright in the Kingmaker before winning the Grade 2 Pendil, a contest we love to target. That victory, over 2m4f, gives us more options for this season, as does the fact he coped surprisingly well with the soft ground at Warwick and Kempton. Whatever happens later this week, it will be fences after that and we'll look for a valuable pot on a flat, right-handed track - something at Ascot would suit ideally. In January, the Grade 2 Silviniaco Conti Chase over two and a half miles is another decent prize I'd consider. He's so tough and consistent that I have no doubt he'll be adding to his tally. 04-11-25

runners.comment: Returns to action after an injury; exciting and unbeaten youngster who is the one to beat
runners.name: Sir Gino

prev_owners.owner: C & Y Lerner, Jean-Paul Deshayes & Pascal Deshayes

quotes.race: Ladbrokes Wayward Lad Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The way Sir Gino did it was frightening, to be honest. He learned over the first couple of fences and then just went. You couldn't see a cleaner performance than that. It's nice Nico [De Boinville, jockey] thinks he's a superstar, but he's got a long way to go still. He's done nothing wrong in his whole life and he's always been a very talented horse with so much scope. Now we've seen what he's done over fences, he certainly can't go back over hurdles and it's pretty obvious where we're going now - Nicky Henderson, trainer.

quotes.race: BetMGM Fighting Fifth Hurdle (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Sir Gino is very, very good. We've always thought it and he's taken a step in that direction. He's a seriously talented horse. He's so good at it [chasing], you haven't seen a horse over fences like that. He's unbelievable. He's like all those good two-milers we've been lucky enough to have, he's as good as we've seen. We'll see how things pan out. We've got a conundrum to come. There's the Christmas Hurdle and then Joe [Donnelly, owner] has got State Man as well so we've got to play the cards to suit his game. That [performance] would say do we need to be going chasing this season? - Nicky Henderson, trainer, speaking on ITV Racing.

quotes.race: Boodles Anniversary 4-Y-O Juvenile Hurdle (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It was a messy sort of race, they were playing cat and mouse a bit. It was stop-start and Sir Gino was a bit untidy up the straight, but I was watching the speed gauge and it was varying dramatically. They slowed up and quickened up. Still, he's done what he had to do. He's very good and hopefully he's got a long way to go. He's in at Punchestown, I put him in case we had protesters or a bomb scare or something stupid but I wouldn't have thought that will be very high on our agenda. Sticking to hurdles would have to be the plan for next season, we're not going to think about discussing it now but we'll have to see - Nicky Henderson, trainer.

quotes.race: JCB Triumph Trial Juvenile Hurdle (Grade 2) (Registered As The Finesse) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Sir Gino is very good. He's always told us that, but he learned a lot at Kempton last time. We've all been quite bullish about him, but rather reluctant to say too much in case we end up with egg on our face, but he's smart. He'd jump a fence, so we've got to look after the future as well as the present. That was impressive and he's a very talented individual - there's no doubt about that - Nicky Henderson, trainer.

quotes.race: ladbrokeslive.co.uk To Win Free Music Tickets "Introductory" Juvenile Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Sir Gino is progressing all of the time and will have learned a lot today. It's just a case of keeping his mind on the job and keeping him concentrating as much as anything. He was just losing a bit of concentration but that's the first time he's seen a big crowd. He's a proper horse. Someone has to take on Burdett Road and we may as well give it a go. He's still a baby but is growing up all the time - Nico de Boinville, jockey.

runners.spotlight: Exciting and unbeaten youngster who was impressive in the Fighting Fifth over hurdles at Newcastle (2m, good) and the Wayward Lad over fences at the Kempton Christmas festival (2m, good to soft) last term, appearing to have the world at his feet; subsequently picked up a serious injury but is thankfully back in action and reverts to this sphere with the Champion Hurdle the aim; should be difficult to beat, provided he picks up where he left off.

stable_tour.quote: His campaign came to a very abrupt halt due to an issue caused by an infection to his near hind lower limb, which had somehow invaded his suspensory ligament. It was a million-to-one job, but it happens. What causes it, nobody knows, but we think and hope we're back, although we're never going to be out of the woods, in that I suppose it could reoccur. We're going to tiptoe very daintily through the tulips. He's unbeaten to date and remains about as exciting as you can get, most especially over fences, but I have little doubt that the Champion Hurdle was within his reach. Unfortunately, we've lost our novice status as a chaser and the programme will now dictate where we go, but he's undoubtedly a two-miler. It all hinges on whether he can cope again with the rigours of training and racing -  if he can, the world is at his feet. 21-10-25

runners.comment: Sole win at Kempton resulted in Dovecote novice win but this is a stiffer assignment
runners.name: Tripoli Flyer

quotes.race: Ladbrokes Dovecote Novices' Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Tripoli Flyer has got a huge engine. Johnny said you can put him where you want in a race, he's got an explosive bit of speed about him. He thought he could have waited a bit longer maybe but he got the job done and we were here to win this. I think he's genuinely better going right-handed and he does jump a bit right, but if it's nice ground I think he's earned his chance to go to the Supreme. He's won plenty now and definitely deserves a go - Fergal O'Brien, trainer.  We'll have a coffee on Monday morning and see where we go. I feel like Aintree owes us one after Tripoli Flyer got beat there last year although I have to be careful what I say as we were beaten by the stable's other runner! - Ismail El Magdoub, owner.

runners.spotlight: Reverts to hurdles after two unsuccessful attempts over fences; sole appearance at Kempton resulted in Grade 2 Dovecote novice win in February but this is a much stiffer task; his chance of making an impact therefore partly depends on how well he responds to first-time headgear.

stable_tour.quote: He's going for the Dovecote first and we'll see how that goes. I was impressed with him at Musselburgh ? once Johnny [Burke] opened him up he really came alive, and I loved the way he jumped when they were going fast. Hopefully he can go well at Kempton and then go on to Cheltenham. Better ground will suit. 18-2-25

runners.comment: Fortuitous winner of the Champion Hurdle and Fighting Fifth but is still a major contender
runners.name: Golden Ace

quotes.race: BetMGM Fighting Fifth Hurdle (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I couldn't come up with a reason not to run. I didn't want to, I wanted to give Golden Ace more time, but the trouble was it was either run here or wait until Kempton and I thought this would suit her better than Kempton. We said we'd run her here today then if everything went well we'd probably go to the International and then to the Champion Hurdle, that's the plan - Jeremy Scott, trainer.

quotes.race: bet365 Mares' Hurdle (Listed Race) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Lorcan said Golden Ace felt great going into the bend then when Harry Skelton kicked she just flattened out. She's probably not as straight as I thought she was but even so it's disappointing. We've probably come up against a very match-fit horse and we knew she wasn't fully wound up but it was disappointing. Maybe something will come out in the wash. You always want an excuse, you want a reason. It's frustrating. I'm sorry she didn't run better, I got up blooming early to get here this morning and I was hoping for a good run. She was full of beans and been going so well at home - Jeremy Scott, trainer.

quotes.race: Unibet Champion Hurdle Challenge Trophy (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Golden Ace is fantastic and always turns up and runs her race. Jeremy and his team have done a great job and fair play to Ian [Gosden, owner] for picking this race. We wanted to go for the Mares' but I'm not complaining now. Ian's bravery has been rewarded. When Constitution Hill was out of the race, I thought we might stay on for second, and then when State Man fell at the last, we were there to pick up the pieces, which was the game plan - Lorcan Williams, rider.

quotes.race: BetMGM Kingwell Hurdle (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I'm so delighted, didn't Golden Ace tough it out? The front two were really tough and she's really had to battle there. She didn't travel as well as I thought she should and her jumping at times wasn't as good as it could be. Halfway round I was tying the knot on the noose  That's huge for us. We'll have to head to Cheltenham now and make a decision as to where we go. We didn't have heaps in hands over Burdett Road which we might need to be if we're going for a Champion Hurdle but over two and a half miles she's not looked like she's seen it out.  She seems back to her best which is great - Jeremy Scott, trainer.

quotes.race: Changing Young Lives At Jamie's Farm Mares' Novices' Hurdle (Listed Race) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I think Golden Ace is ten times better on softer ground but she did it well and she's got one hell of an engine. Her jumping still needs to improve a little bit and that's something we can improve. I'm very lucky and fortunate to ride her and hopefully we can nick a Grade 1 somewhere - Lorcan Williams, rider.

quotes.race: Ryanair Mares' Novices' Hurdle (Grade 2) (Registered As The Dawn Run Mares' Novices' Hurdle) (GBB)
quotes.quote: Golden Ace is not one that tears the gallops up, in all honesty, but her racing has always been really good. She was so cool and calm in the paddock; she takes everything in her stride and it's just such an asset. It doesn't look like she will jump a fence, so I think we will stick with hurdles. But we've got lots to dream about and we will enjoy this moment, reflect on it tomorrow and think of a good plan - Jeremy Scott, trainer.

quotes.race: Stables Business Park Mares' Novices' Hurdle (Herring Queen Series Qualifier) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We were a bit worried about the ground, which had dried out a bit, but Golden Ace handled it fine. We came here as she needed to slicken up her jumping if she's to tackle bigger targets such as the Mares' Novices' at the festival, although I wouldn't rule out a tilt at the final of this series at Kelso -  Trainer Jeremy Scott, speaking on RacingTV.

quotes.race: Farmers Friend Novices' Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The main thing was to get Golden Ace jumping and gain some experience and anything else was a bonus. We're delighted with that as she is back from a setback that meant she had to have a wind op. Hopefully she can tackle something more appealing after that - Lorcan Williams, jockey.

runners.spotlight: Gained her Grade 1 wins in fortuitous fashion, having benefited from the falls of major rivals in the Champion Hurdle last season and Fighting Fifth on latest start, both on good to soft ground; however, she's still one of the main players, with her sex allowance again coming in handy.

stable_tour.quote: She scoped very dirty after her disappointing comeback at Wetherby, which made me look a fool, but she's grand now. We've a couple more checks to do before we commit to the Fighting Fifth, but that's vaguely the plan. Last season was magic and it would be lovely to prove what happened in the Champion Hurdle wasn't a fluke. I just want a clean run so we can knuckle down and prove she's more capable than a lot of people give us credit for. We're a little bit limited in options, but it's important to get some runs into her before Cheltenham in March and races like the Christmas Hurdle, Relkeel and International will be considered. The Champion Hurdle is the ultimate aim. 23-11-25

14:30.race_name: Ladbrokes King George VI Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)

runners.comment: Won this last season but disappointing on his three starts this year; a visor goes on
runners.name: Banbridge

quotes.race: Boodles Cheltenham Gold Cup Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Banbridge didn't jump well enough - J J Slevin, jockey.

quotes.race: Ladbrokes King George VI Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It was a special win. Banbridge has been a special horse for a number of years and is such a dream. Speed is emphasised here more than some places and I think that panned out well for him, but I did think Il Est Francais had gone and won. We'll enjoy today and will discuss plans later. After Punchestown last year Ronnie [Bartlett, owner] called me and said let's have a go at the King George and that paid off. We really felt he was ready to run his legs off - Joseph O'Brien, trainer.

quotes.race: William Hill Champion Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: I thought JJ [Slevin, jockey] gave Banbridge a fantastic ride and the tempo of the race wasn't quite what we thought it'd be. He saved a bit and the horse found a lot and I'm delighted for Ronnie [Bartlett, owner] as he's been very patient with this horse, particularly when the ground hasn't been right for him. We weren't sure if we'd go three miles or two, but it became obvious when El Fabiolo went to Sandown. He's pretty versatile, and Ronnie's even mentioned the King George as an early season target next year but he'll be kept on as good ground as we can find for him. He's remarkably consistent when he has his conditions - Joseph O'Brien, trainer, speaking on Racing TV.

quotes.race: Coral Silviniaco Conti Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We've been looking for good ground and we got it today. Banbridge looked a bit rusty at times and made a few mistakes but he's been off the track for a long time, so it's pretty exciting. He's more mature and he was very cool about travelling over here. We've had him bubbling for a while and there have been races that we've been going for and the ground wasn't the way we wanted, but hopefully there's a bit of improvement to come. If the ground is nice he'll go for the Ryanair; it would be nice to take Michael O'Leary's money! - Ronnie Bartlett, owner.

quotes.race: Racehorse Lotto Manifesto Novices' Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Banbridge ran in the Drinmore earlier in the season and after that race we knew he's a better horse on better ground so there's no point wasting runs on soft ground. I think we probably saw the result of minding him earlier in the spring here today. I declared him on Saturday just in case, when I saw there was rain coming yesterday I wanted to be sure before I walked the track this morning but he won't run again. We'll look at Punchestown and see how he comes out of this. You'd have to say looking at him today that he could stay further in time. But he's certainly not slow - Joseph O'Brien, trainer.

quotes.race: From The Horses Mouth Podcast Arkle Challenge Trophy Trial Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Banbridge has taken to chasing very well. He's already gone a step ahead of his hurdles campaign and there's a long way to go until the next step but you couldn't be more impressed with what he's done there. He's a hugely exciting horse going forwards. I think we learned today that two miles is another option going forwards, his jumping was what you wanted to see from a two-miler - Joseph O'Brien, trainer.

quotes.race: Join Gowran Park Racing Club Beginners Chase
quotes.quote: Banbridge jumped very well. We had schooled him a bit at home and he has been very good. You'd be hoping he might achieve something similar to what he achieved over hurdles - J.J. Slevin, rider.

quotes.race: Martin Pipe Conditional Jockeys' Handicap Hurdle (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: The standing start actually suited us. Banbridge was very sharp away, thank God, and I got a lovely position early. They didn't go very quick and he was always in his comfort zone. I wasn't confident that I would win until about ten strides after the last. I was always just conscious that something might get to me, but luckily nothing did - Mark McDonagh, rider.

quotes.race: Dunmoe Rated Novice Hurdle
quotes.quote: It was a nice performance for a horse that really wants further. Banbridge will be a three-miler in time. I just thought that they might do him for a bit of toe but he's very tough and he jumped well up the straight. He wouldn't want it any softer than that. Next year he could be an exciting chaser, especially at 2m4f or further. He'll stay 3m. He stays, he's honest and he gallops - Brendan Powell, assistant trainer.

runners.spotlight: Three-time Grade 1 winner, including of this race last season when wearing refitted cheekpieces; however, he's been disappointing on his three starts this year (no headgear on latest) and hopes are pinned on the return to Kempton and the first-time visor sparking a major revival.

stable_tour.quote: I'm happy with how he's done during the summer. We missed Navan this year but there's a fair chance he might go to the Hilly Way again at Cork. If that went well, we might look to go back to Kempton for the King George, which he won last year. We'll take it step by step with him after that. 23-11-25

A very smart novice chaser who won twice earlier this season, including the Arkle trial at Cheltenham's November meeting. His last run was a fair effort when second to El Fabiolo who has not done the form any harm since. We missed Cheltenham last month with him as the ground was too soft, but he is in very good order and he is going to Aintree on Thursday for the Manifesto Novices' Chase which is a Grade 1 over 2m4f. He will be up against Stage Star amd Saint Roi so it won't be easy. His work has been very encouraging though. 12-04-23

runners.comment: 0-5 in Grade 1s but he's only seven and has won two Grade 2s under penalties this season
runners.name: Djelo

quotes.race: Sky Bet Peterborough Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: He [Saint Sam] has been a front running in the past so the assumption was he would go and make the running, but Charlie [Deutsch] quite rightly allowed that for a certain point and he clearly wasn't going quick enough, at which point Charlie thought he needed to make sure it was the right test for him and not worry about that horse anymore. It was [a good display last year], but it is hard to compare one with another. It is every bit as good for sure. As I said after Wetherby I think a lot of the good horses, which you have got to say Djelo is one of the good horses, I don't think they have finite distances really, as long as they are quick enough for shorter and stay further. Charlie said after the last, and he said all the way up the run-in that he was thinking of the King George, so he kept a bit in the tank. It is something to look forward to now. I think the only thing one can say is that he deserves to take his chance in the race. Furthermore, that is the obvious thing to do now and there aren't other races you would be considering around that same period. He was the youngest horse in the race today, and there is still plenty of time to have a long career ahead of him - Venetia Williams, trainer.I was conscious of pace in the race and expected the Irish horse to lead, but when he dropped out we were in front sooner than last year, so we went from there. Djelo did that well and that was probably his most impressive win - Charlie Deutsch, jockey.

quotes.race: bet365 Charlie Hall Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I was really thrilled. It was quite a fight. I thought Djelo was going to win, then I thought he was going to get beaten. Pic D'Orhy is obviously a very talented horse. It was quite a battle to the line. He's a seven-year-old, that's easy to forget. He's achieved a lot. Let's hope he can go on again. We've got to go back for the Peterborough again, haven't we? I know it's a step back in trip but there's no reason why he can't be so effective. He certainly was last year - Venetia Williams, trainer.

quotes.race: William Hill Bet10 Get10 On Racing Denman Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: We've got Djelo in the Ryanair and Champion Chase and I would say it will be straight to the Ryanair. We left the tactics to Charlie [Deutsch, jockey] and we didn't want him to be too keen, so he dropped him right out and settled beautifully. Once he set him alight, the turbo kicked in very quickly - Venetia Williams, trainer.

quotes.race: Trustatrader Peterborough Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Djelo is so clever at the obstacles - whether it's long, short, tight or whatever he's so quick and he's such an intelligent horse. He was third at the Cheltenham Festival in the Turners and he won three races last season, but he's been progressive ever since his attention was turned to fences and let's hope that's continuing - Venetia Williams, trainer.

quotes.race: BetMGM Haldon Gold Cup Handicap Chase (Grade 2) (Limited Handicap Chase) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Djelo has done very well. He just had a bit of bad luck. He met the last one on a bit of an awkward stride and he met a few like that. He just ran out of racecourse to catch him. In fairness the winner was always cantering, but I have to be really pleased as he has run a super race and he has galloped all the way to the line - Venetia Williams, trainer.

quotes.race: Howden Noel Novices' Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I'm very pleased. Like many of ours, once they go chasing they tend to step up. We always thought Djelo was a nice horse. He won a low-key race fairly easily last season and then didn't manage to progress but with these young, potential chasers you just have to let it go. He's not the biggest horse in the world but he's very nimble. Charlie came back in with a big smile on his face. I think he could go up or down in trip as he's showing speed and a degree of stamina. We haven't tested that stamina hugely yet, but he's galloped right to the line -  Venetia Williams, trainer.

quotes.race: BoyleSports Money Back 2nd Meeting Handicap Chase
quotes.quote: Djelo is really hardy and kept finding. He jumped well and has lots of scope. He stays well and has grown up a bit - Charlie Deutsch, jockey.

runners.spotlight: He's come up short on the five previous occasions he's tackled a Grade 1; however, he's only seven and has been in fine form this season, winning Grade 2s under penalties at Wetherby (3m, good) and Huntingdon (2m4f, soft); given how right-handed, flat Huntingdon suits him, there can be optimism that he'll also excel here (today is his first visit) and he's an each-way player.

stable_tour.quote: He had a wonderful season last term and showed his versatility by winning the Peterborough Chase over two and a half miles and the Denman Chase over almost three miles. The plan at Newbury had been to run in the Game Spirit and I only entered him in the Denman with five minutes to go based on how the entries were shaping up. He could start off in the Haldon Gold Cup again, having finished second in it last season, but we wouldn't want to run on quick ground over a trip that short on his first run back, and his first major target will likely be the Peterborough again. He's still only seven and there's lots to look forward to. 22-10-25

runners.comment: 4 Grade 1 wins; suspicion a shorter trip is optimal, but a leading candidate nevertheless
runners.name: Fact To File

quotes.race: Ryanair Chase (Registered As The Festival Trophy) (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: They went a good gallop, Fact To File stayed with them and got all his jumping right, and off the bend, I don't think Mark was worried; he just had to get over the last two fences and he did that well. The manner of the way in which he won was a bit of a surprise, but I felt coming here he'd win it. But the others were good horses, anyone would love to have them. I do agree that he might have been the horse to give Galopin Des Champs a battle in the Gold Cup and he was in it, but he felt it was better to bide our options. He'll probably be a Gold Cup horse next year. He'll be a year older and we felt that at this stage a hard race in the Gold Cup, if the ground turned up soft... It's not like that, but that was the way I was thinking all season. JP [McManus] didn't want him to have a very hard race in the Gold Cup this year - sometimes that can ruin a horse's career. So next year - I'm not going to say any more about two-year plans after Lossiemouth, but another year might be right. I think that's what we're looking at - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: John Durkan Memorial Punchestown Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: I was really taken by Fact To File and what he did from the last to the winning post. I thought he was beaten by Spillane's Tower, but Fact To File put his head down. Mark said he took a blow at the last but put his head back down. He could end up Leopardstown at Christmas as he's not in the King George - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Brown Advisory Novices' Chase (Grade 1) (Registered As The Broadway Novices' Chase) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I felt Fact To File was a ready-made steeplechaser from the first day he came into the yard, so that's why we skipped hurdling with him. I'm very happy we did that with him now, and I think JP had a nice wager on him for this race for the staff at the start of the season. He's a beautiful jumper and he gave Mark (Walsh) a tremendous ride. I'd say it was some thrill riding him around there. He's just a real gentleman of a horse, and definitely a Gold Cup horse in the making - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Ladbrokes Novice Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: Fact To File looked as good as we hoped and I've loved him from the first day he came into the stable. He always looked to have a good future ahead of him. Things are working out for him. I'll have a word with JP and Frank (Berry, racing manager). I don't have a preference (for Cheltenham). This weekend was going to tell us a lot about which horses will run in which races - Willie Mullins, trainer, speaking to Racing TV.

quotes.race: Ballymaloe Relish Rising Stars Beginners Chase
quotes.quote: Fact Or File is a horse I've loved since the first day he came into the stable. I think he could go the whole way, with a bit of luck - Willie Mullins, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Four-time Grade 1 winner, including at the last two Cheltenham Festivals, namely in the Brown Advisory Novices' Chase (3m, soft) and the Ryanair Chase (2m4f, good to soft); returned from a break with a neck second to Gaelic Warrior in the John Durkan Memorial Chase (2m3f, soft to heavy) last month; there's a suspicion a shorter trip is optimal but he ran two big races in 3m Grade 1s at Leopardstown last winter and is a leading candidate today.

stable_tour.quote: It makes sense to start off in the John Durkan given he won it last year. He won the Ryanair convincingly last season and, given JP [McManus] owns the Gold Cup winner, I'd imagine the Ryanair will be his main target again this season. He's good enough to be a Gold Cup contender and now he's a year older and stronger he might stay the trip better, but at this stage the Ryanair would be on my radar unless things change during the season. 17-11-25
He's coming along well. He won his first bumper at Leopardstown and returned there for the Dublin Racing Festival, where he ran a nice race to be second in a Grade 2. . 08-03-23

runners.comment: 7yo who has won his last three, including two Grade 1s, and there's lots to like
runners.name: Gaelic Warrior

quotes.race: John Durkan Memorial Punchestown Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: It was exciting for me! Gaelic Warrior was fresh and wanted to get on with it, so I let him run to the first and he ran a lot longer than that. It was a proper horse race and I had a willing partner, that's for sure. I did for a stride [think Fact To File would win when he came to challenge], yeah. The concern was the petrol tank emptying but I didn't know how much ground Mark had had to make up and whether he had to do it on his own.  I knew I wasn't going to stop, but it was looking unlikely for a second [that he would win]. He's a very talented horse - Paul Townend, jockey.

quotes.race: bet365 Oaksey Chase (Grade 2) (For The Menorah Challenge Trophy) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I didn't mind the ground or the trip today - it was just whether Gaelic Warrior had recovered from his last race at Aintree. I think Punchestown will come too soon and we have an open mind about him. Maybe we'll look at stepping up for the King Geroge. There are lots of options open to him - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Brooklands Golden Miller Chronograph Bowl Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It's great that Patrick [Mullins, jockey] got on Gaelic Warrior. I thought Paul [Townend] would ride him, but he chose Embassy Gardens. His main target was to get him round in one piece, and then if he was able to do that we all know he has the class. I'd been a little disappointed in his two previous runs, when he just didn't fire, but he'd run well enough at Leopardstown and we thought he'd be better for it, but then he just wasn't right for Cheltenham. I thought if I didn't run him here I'd have to wait until Punchestown, so I thought we may as well run him here to get a race into him anyhow, so he's done a bit more than that - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Paddy's Rewards Club Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior just took a blow before the third last and I had to sit on him, but he has run on well. The winner is hard fit and probably got away - Patrick Mullins, jockey.

quotes.race: My Pension Expert Arkle Challenge Trophy Novices' Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior jumped a lot straighter, there were two fences he shifted right just to sort himself out. Stamina came into play today and we know he stays. I just pointed him the right way! That's the best ride I've got off Gaelic Warrior in a long time. He was very manageable once we got out on to the track. Willie's done an unbelievable job on him - Paul Townend, jockey, speaking to ITV Racing. You can see what a difference a hood made to him, he wasn't inclined to jump right and Paul could ride the race on him. I was sort of asking myself as he was coming down the hill, 'what were we doing in three-mile races last year with him?' I think he has enough class now to do two miles, and he will probably stick at that game now, after that performance - Willie Mullins, trainer, speaking to ITV Racing.

quotes.race: Guinness Faugheen Novice Chase (Grade 1)
quotes.quote: Two of Gaelic Warrior's defeats have been at Cheltenham going left-handed. Cheltenham doesn't really suit him. The Turners is run on the New course, which is not as tight as the Old course, but he is better going right-handed. Going left-handed at Leopardstown in February is one option, maybe we should try it and see. The way he jumps, this might be his best trip, perhaps two miles on soft ground. He is very versatile. A lot of credit goes to Rachel Robbins, who rides him out and looks after him - Patrick Mullins, jockey.

quotes.race: Ballymore Novices' Hurdle (Grade 1) (Registered As The Baring Bingham) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior took out his earplugs on the way to the start and he didn't settle as well as we'd want him to, but Patrick said he could go up to three miles. He'll be a big, strong chaser down the line - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Festina Lente Charity Liffey Handicap Hurdle (Grade B)
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior has a bit of class and he proved it there, to do that in a competitive handicap was very good. We always thought he had a serious engine and he's progressing all the time. He's in the Supreme and Ballymore, I'll have a good chat with Paul later on and see what direction we go with him.  We'll see what the fall out of this weekend is and see what we have for different races. He's inclined to go right but that seems to be only when he has the space to do that. He was very good even when he went right - Willie Mullins, trainer.

quotes.race: Munster Hurdle
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior was quite fresh in himself at the start but he was grand after that. He's a lovely horse, it was hard work out there and he is quite hard on himself. He prefers to go right handed - Paul Townend, rider.

quotes.race: Boodles Juvenile Handicap Hurdle (Registered as The Fred Winter) (Grade 3) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: Gaelic Warrior ran a great race. On the whole he jumped well. We would have probably liked a bit more juice in the ground. He is a nice prospect for next season. It didn't help him how he jumped the last but that is racing. There was only a short head in it and you can if an and all day but he ran a great race. I hope there will be plenty of good days with him as he is a real jumping type. We will stay novice hurdling next season as he is still a maiden and he will be back here for the Ballymore next year - Willie Mullins, trainer.

runners.spotlight: Won the 2024 Arkle over 2m and this 7yo was very well suited by the step up in trip when impressive in the Grade 1 Bowl at Aintree (3m1f, good to soft) in April; 2-2 since (2m6f/2m3f, good/soft to heavy), last time by a neck from Fact To File at Punchestown; there's lots to like.

stable_tour.quote: We're going to give him a crack at the King George if all goes well. He went out on a high last season by winning at Aintree and Sandown and we might kick off his season in the John Durkan before heading over to Kempton at Christmas. We could go back to Aintree and Sandown towards the end of the season, but my priority is to try to get him ready for the King George. It's a race that should really suit him. 17-11-25

He was beaten a short head in the juvenile handicap hurdle at the festival 12 months ago on his debut for us, which although disappointing was a big effort. Since then he has really found his stride and improved with each run - in fact, the handicapper thinks he's 24lb better now. He won his first two races this season by an aggregate of 101 lengths and we then had the option of taking on Facile Vega and Il Etait Temps in a Grade 1. But it would have been a sin not to go for the big handicap at the Dublin Racing Festival off his mark of 143. We had the option of that race or the Betfair Hurdle, but we thought it best to stay at home with Cheltenham so close. And he did just as we expected by winning it nicely. There's the option of going for the Supreme, but at the moment he's more likely to go for the Ballymore. He's still progressing. 08-03-23

runners.comment: Very up and down, pulled up at Ascot latest; Kempton factor means he's worth a second look
runners.name: Il Est Francais

quotes.race: Ladbrokes 1965 Chase (Grade 2) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: It wasn't the day we were looking for. A lot of head-scratching goes in with Il Est Francais, trying to work out exactly what's what. He's fine this morning. He's had blips all the way through his career and I think we have to carry on. I chatted with Noel [George] and Amanda [Zetterholm, previous trainers] this morning, and we've just got to carry on, as we did last year, and hope everything falls the right way. Four weeks before the King George last year he pulled up. Hopefully, we'll get him back to Kempton in the same form he was in last year. I think we've just got to keep our heads down, puff our chests out and carry on. We'll probably do a few different things training-wise with him, but we've just got to keep going the same as last year - Tom George, trainer, speaking the following day.

quotes.race: Ladbrokes King George VI Chase (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I was just going really easy like last year. I felt like I was in second gear all the way around. I looked behind me and I was 20 lengths clear and I couldn't believe it. I just ran out of petrol coming to two out, but Il Est Francais has been very brave and he was a good second. I met the last wrong and I didn't feel like I had enough gas to ask him for a long one so I had to pop it and he was brave and gutsy. We were beaten by a better horse on the day. It is onwards and upwards. Maybe a drop back in trip might be on the agenda. He might be a Ryanair type - James Reveley, rider.

quotes.race: Grand Steeple-Chase Masters - Prix Murat (Chase) (Grade 2) (5yo+) (Turf)
quotes.quote: I'm sure there'll be something amiss because it was too bad to be true really. I was happy enough throughout the race, I wanted to change tactics, drop in and get him settled looking towards the Grand Steeple. I didn't think we went very fast and Il Est Francais did a big jump at the Riviere [des Tribunes] so I let him go on, without going too fast. I was happy until the last bend and then I felt him really empty, there was nothing left. I was going to pull up but I popped the last. He was walking - James Reveley, rider.

quotes.race: Ladbrokes Kauto Star Novices' Chase (In Memory Of Nigel Clark) (Grade 1) (GBB Race)
quotes.quote: I'm just delighted that Il Est Francais has been able to come over here and show everyone just how good he is. He made a couple of mistakes today but he was very, very good otherwise and he has an incredible cruising speed. He takes my breath away every morning on the gallops. He doesn't have to go in front, he has just got that cruising speed. I never work him in front at home as he does too much. He always sits in behind and quickens past them. He is a horse with so many different options. The dream this season is to win the French Gold Cup as his breeder, who owns half of him with Richard Kelvin-Hughes, did everything he did to keep him trained in France to win a French Gold Cup and that is our main aim this season.
